paperAbstract.text: A computer program is described that is designed to reconstruct the metric configuration of a set of points in Euclidean space on the basis of essentially nonmetric information about that configuration. A minimum set of Cartesian coordinates for the points is determined when the only available information specifies for each pair of those points—not the distance between them—but some unknown, fixed monotonic function of that distance. The program is proposed as a tool for reductively analyzing several types of psychological data, particularly measures of interstimulus similarity or confusability, by making explicit the multidimensional structure underlying such data.

title.text: The analysis of proximities: Multidimensional scaling with an unknown distance function. I.

tldr.text: The program is proposed as a tool for reductively analyzing several types of psychological data, particularly measures of interstimulus similarity or confusability, by making explicit the multidimensional structure underlying such data.

paperAbstract.text: The first in the present series of two papers described a computer program for multidimensional scaling on the basis of essentially nonmetric data. This second paper reports the results of two kinds of test applications of that program. The first application is to artificial data generated by monotonically transforming the interpoint distances in a known spatial configuration. The purpose is to show that the recovery of the original metric configuration does not depend upon the particular transformation used. The second application is to measures of interstimulus similarity and confusability obtained from some actual psychological experiments.

title.text: The analysis of proximities: Multidimensional scaling with an unknown distance function. II

tldr.text: The results of two kinds of test applications of a computer program for multidimensional scaling on the basis of essentially nonmetric data are reported to measures of interstimulus similarity and confusability obtained from some actual psychological experiments.

paperAbstract.text: Given the preference ordering of each of a number of individuals over a set of stimuli, it is proposed that if the preference orderings are generated in a Euclidean space ofr dimensions which can be recovered by unfolding the preference orderings, then a factor analysis of the correlations between individual's preference orderings will yield a space ofr + 1 dimensions with the originalr-space embedded in it, and the additional dimension will be one of social utility. The proposition is clearly shown to be satisfied by means of the Monte Carlo technique for both random and lattice stimuli in three dimensions and for two other examples with random stimuli in one and two dimensions.

title.text: On a connection between factor analysis and multidimensional unfolding

tldr.text: The proposition that a factor analysis of the correlations between individual's preference orderings will yield a space ofr + 1 dimensions with the originalr-space embedded in it, and the additional dimension will be one of social utility is shown to be satisfied.

paperAbstract.text: The purpose of this paper is to present and illustrate a new method, in fact the first method, for the nonmetric multidimensional analysis of similarity data, perhaps better to be understood as nonmetric mu$idimensional psychophysics. The method has been developed by a colleague, William Hays, at the University of Michigan, and it grew out of his thesis work on the multidimensional unfolding of preferential choice behavior (3 ) . His manuscript on this new method3 is now in preparation. First I shall say a little about the problem of similarity, the kind of data that may be involved, and the usual method of analyzing it, then I shall discuss Hays' nonmetric model and present an application of it to a Morse code confusion matrix. The problem of similarity is fundamental to many surveillance operations that involve pattern recognition. For instance, in the interpretation of optical, infra-red or radar photographs, or interpretation of received communications signals or in the judgment of military situations, officers are continually faced with the problem of making such judgments. I don't need to dwell on the general significance of the problem of similarity to psychology. Attneave, in his paper on the dimensions of similarity ( I ) , points out its use as an intervening variable in theories about perceptual organization, association, transfer, and retroactive inhibition. These very phenomena might themselves be used to define and measure similarity but then, of course, the concept cannot be used to explain the same phenomena used to define and measure it. Consequently, one finds no uniformity in the literature on this problem. A great variety of response measures can be and have been used as the source data for measuring similarity. These include: amplitude of response, latency, probability or consistency, judgment of similarity, confusion matrices, matching behavior ( Same-Diff erent ) , GSRs, and so forth. I think an essential element of what characterizes what we mean by

title.text: An Application of a Nonmetric Model for Multidimensional Analysis of Similarities

tldr.text: A new method, in fact the first method, for the nonmetric multidimensional analysis of similarity data, perhaps better to be understood as nonmetrics mu$idimensional psychophysics is presented.

paperAbstract.text: A mathematical model is developed in an attempt to relate errors in multiple stimulus-response situations to psychological inter-stimulus and inter response distances. The fundamental assumptions are (a) that the stimulus and response confusions go on independently of each other, (b) that the probability of a stimulus confusion is an exponential decay function of the psychological distance between the stimuli, and (c) that the probability of a response confusion is an exponential decay function of the psychological distance between the responses. The problem of the operational definition of psychological distance is considered in some detail.

title.text: Stimulus and response generalization: A stochastic model relating generalization to distance in psychological space

paperAbstract.text: We describe the numerical methods required in our approach to multi-dimensional scaling. The rationale of this approach has appeared previously.

title.text: Nonmetric multidimensional scaling: A numerical method

tldr.text: The numerical methods required in the approach to multi-dimensional scaling are described and the rationale of this approach has appeared previously.

paperAbstract.text: A recently developed method is described for the reductive analysis of confusion matrices by means of a high-speed digital computer. Illustrative applications of this method to several previously published matrices of the confusions between signals of the Morse code are presented for the first time. The results seem to provide useful information about how these dot-and-dash patterns are processed in man.

title.text: Analysis of Proximities as a Technique for the Study of Information Processing in Man1

paperAbstract.text: A model for visual recall tasks was presented in terms of visual information storage (VIS), scanning, rehearsal, and auditory information storage (AIS). It was shown first that brief visual stimuli are stored in VIS in a form similar to the sensory input. These visual “images” contain considerably more information than is transmitted later. They can be sampled by scanning for items at high rates of about 10 msec per letter. Recall is based on a verbal receding of the stimulus (rehearsal), which is remembered in AIS. The items retained in AIS are usually rehearsed again to prevent them from decaying. The human limits in immediate-memory (reproduction) tasks are inherent in the AIS-Rehearsal loop. The main implication of the model for human factors is the importance of the auditory coding in visual tasks.

title.text: A Model for Visual Memory Tasks1

tldr.text: A model for visual recall tasks was presented in terms of visual information storage, scanning, rehearsal, and auditory information storage and the main implication of the model for human factors is the importance of the auditory coding in visual tasks.
